abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Complex developmental encephalopathy syndromes might be the consequence of unknown genetic alterations that are likely to contribute to the full neurological phenotype as a consequence of pathogenic gene combinations.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>To identify the additional genetic contribution to the neurological phenotype, we studied as a test case a boy, with a <jats:italic>KCNQ</jats:italic>2 exon-7 partial duplication, by single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) microarray to detect copy-number variations (CNVs).</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The proband presented a cerebral palsy like syndrome with a severe motor and developmental encephalopathy. The SNP array analysis detected in the proband several de novo CNVs, nine partial gene losses (<jats:italic>LRRC55</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>PCDH9</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>NALCN</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>RYR3</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>ELAVL2</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CDH13</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>ATP1A2</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>SLC17A5</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>ANO3</jats:italic>), and two partial gene duplications (<jats:italic>PCDH19</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>EFNA5</jats:italic>). The biological functions of these genes are associated with ion channels such as calcium, chloride, sodium, and potassium with several membrane proteins implicated in neural cell-cell interactions, synaptic transmission, and axon guidance. Pathogenically, these functions can be associated to cerebral palsy, seizures, dystonia, epileptic crisis, and motor neuron dysfunction, all present in the patient.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Severe motor and developmental encephalopathy syndromes of unknown origin can be the result of a phenotypic convergence by combination of several genetic alterations in genes whose physiological function contributes to the neurological pathogenic mechanism.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All participants were provided with an explanation of the genetic study research, and written informed consent for the diagnostic genetic study was obtained from the parents of the affected child. The genomic diagnostic study was approved by the ethics committee of the Hospital Universitario de Salamanca and Hospital Sant Joan de Deu.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Written informed consent for publication was obtained from the participant’s legal guardian/next of kin.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare they have no competing interests.

funder.name: Consejería de Educación, Junta de Castilla y León
Departament de Salut, Generalitat de Catalunya
